project_meta.name: Apple_Tier_Liquid_Glass_Experience
project_meta.description: A production-grade, motion-first landing page featuring physics-based 'Liquid Glass' materials, refraction, and scroll-linked storytelling.
project_meta.core_philosophy: Apple Quality: High friction, high reward. Every interaction has weight/inertia. No static elements.

typography.font_family: SF Pro Display, Inter, or Geist Sans

GlobalCanvas.description: A full-screen R3F Canvas that sits behind the UI (z-index: 0).

Hero_Liquid_Object.interaction: The object slowly rotates and distorts on its own. On scroll, it morphs or moves to the side.

Glass_UI_Panel.style_logic: Does NOT use simple backdrop-filter: blur(). Instead, uses a custom SVG filter for 'edge melt'.

Scroll_Controller.logic: Map scrollYProgress (0 to 1) to 3D Scene Timeline.

mapping.action: Hero Object scales x1.5 and moves Right. Text blurs out.
Glass Panel enters from bottom with spring physics.

Mouse_Interaction.logic: The 3D Glass Object should slightly 'look at' the mouse cursor (parallax) using R3F useFrame state.mouse.

instruction_for_coder: Step 1: Set up Next.js with Lenis Scroll immediately. Step 2: Create the 'Scene' component using <Canvas> and <MeshTransmissionMaterial>. Do NOT use standard <meshPhysicalMaterial> as it lacks the premium refractive quality we need. Step 3: Build the layout where HTML content floats 'above' the 3D canvas. Ensure pointer-events are managed so the user can scroll but still interact with 3D elements if needed. Use 'Leva' for debugging material properties.
